subject: Re: JUnit 4.x and support for Java 1.4

messageBody:
Warning, the following is opinionated.

Since we all perceive the world from our own vantage point - I'm no
exception. In southeast MI a future for automotive manufacturing is not a
foregone conclusion. (Today:
http://www.detnews.com/apps/pbcs.dll/article?AID=/20060914/AUTO01/609140365/
1148 )

A quote from the above article as it relates to Ford Motor Company (not my
employer):

"They've got to get 40 to 50 percent of the people out the door. It's just
got to be a lot smaller company."

In this climate, it is difficult for me to be proponent of a new technology
unless it absolutely (unequivocally) demonstrates business value, a.k.a
"payback". For every hour invested in presenting, clarifying, documenting,
cascading organizational (often hidden) effort - there absolutely must be
more than an hour of effectiveness derived.

I'm not at the point where I can in good faith encourage a (large)
organization to change from using "test" to "@Test" to declare a test method
- while being aware of many (but certainly not all) of the cascading costs
of this position. We can not promote a technology because it is new,
popular or "better". It has to be more effective in a business context.

That's my opinion - and I'm sticking to the "business value" assertion. I'm
willing promote change from "test" to "@Test" if someone appreciating (the
magnitude of) hidden costs associated with large organization technology
change can establish a compelling business case.

At the moment, I'm not seeing the value of the change in my own tests.

_Marvin (MDT)


Posted by: "Mark Levison" mlevison@...   marklevison
Thu Sep 14, 2006 5:53 am (PST)


Once JUnit 4.xxx is back ported it would be possible for you to write your
own base class implementation just as you describe.

>>> MDT - agreed.

...

From experience in the .NET world there is some real advantage to declaring
tests using Attributes/Annotation. It makes it possible to derive your test
class from some other class.


Marvin it sounds like what you want is an upgraded Junit 3.8.1 with better
support for fixture setup/teardown. Is that the case?

>>> MDT - yes. That sounds like the most cost effective approach.

What I want is the declarative approach for building tests (pioneered by
NUnit, used by MBUnit and TestNG) made available to for Java 1.4.

...

Cheers
Mark
